Award.AwardTitle: Instantons, low dimensional topology and knotted graphs
Award.AbstractNarration:
High energy physicists believe that the Yang-Mills Equations model the behavior of quarks. The Yang-Mills Equations turn out to have a remarkably rich mathematical structure. These equations enable the study of models of space-time inaccessible by other means and in addition give tools for the study of the topological structure of DNA. The PI will continue his research on the Yang-Mills equations and their connections to many different parts of mathematics, the study of nonlinear partial differential equations, low dimensional topology, algebraic geometry, representation theory and graph theory.

The PI with study Floer homology invariants for three manifolds and knotted graphs in them. In particular with Peter Kronheimer, the PI is studying a family of Floer homology theories built from connections with a prescribed singularity along knotted graphs in three manifolds. Certain versions of these theories appear to be related to Khovanov-Rozansky SL(N)-homology for foams and the relations will be explored and elucidated. Other versions point to theories more general than Khovanov-Rozansky homology. Yet another rather delicate version appears to have bearing on questions of tri-colorability of spacial graphs, and in particular appears likely to provide novel insight to the question of tri-colorability of planar graphs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to develop tools for understanding the topology of theoretical models of space-time.  These models allow that space-time might have singularities along cosmic strings. These strings can be knotted and can themselves be singular and have the topology of trivalent graphs.  The tools developed for the study of these models of space time connect with the four color map theorem.  A plausible conjecture about the these invariants would give a new proof of the four color theorem. This proof would not require the use of a computer to check a huge number of cases.   

These tools use the differential equations of high energy physics like the Yang-Mills equations. The Yang-Mills equations are believed by physicists to govern the behavior of quarks, the fundamental building blocks of matter.  These equations turn out to be sensitive to the topology of space-time and see subtle, hard to decern differences in the topology of space-time.  The PI has developed and refined tools using the Yang-Mills equations to prove surprising results about potential models.  

During the funding period of the present award the PI was able give more evidence that four color map theorem could be attacked by the tools the PI and his collaborators are developing.  The PI and the PI's students developed many other tools for the study of theoretical models of space-time.  Besides the potenital application to the four color map problem these tools allow the PI and other research to approach long standing questions about these models of spaces time including estimating the how many singularities cosmic strings must undergo to mediate between different potential models.

Modified by: Tomasz S Mrowka

    Dodecahedron with three colored edges
  • The Petersen graph has no three edge coloring. If it appears as a cosmic string it only has exotic states in a certain Yang-Mills theory.
    Tom Mrowka and Peter Kronheimer
    Copyrighted
    Tomasz S Mrowka
    The Petersen graph
